chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we need to solve for the necessary data for Treasury bills in order to determine if it is really a risk-free investment.

**a.** First, we will solve for the arithmetic average by adding the rates of return from $1973-1980$ then dividing the sum by the number of years which is $8$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic average return}&=\dfrac{7.29+7.99+5.87+5.07+5.45+7.64+10.56+12.10}{8}\\[15 pt]
&=7.75
\end{aligned}$$

The arithmetic average return for treasury bills from $1973-1980$ is $7.75\%$

Next, we will solve for the arithmetic average of the consumer price index by using the same concept as above.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic average return}&=\dfrac{8.71+12.34+6.94+4.86+6.70+9.02+13.29+12.52}{8}\\[15 pt]
&=9.30
\end{aligned}$$

The arithmetic average for the consumer price index from $1973-1980$ is $9.30\%$

Taking the square root to get the standard deviation, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\sigma&=2.48
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the treasury bills has a standard deviation of $2.48\%$

Taking the square root to get the standard deviation, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\sigma&=3.12
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the inflation has a standard deviation of $3.12\%$

**c.** The real return refers to the return wherein the inflation is already taken into consideration. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+\text{Nominal return}}{1+\text{Inflation rate}}+1
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the real return for $1973$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+7.29}{1+8.71}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.85\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.85\%$

Solving for the real return for $1974$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+7.99}{1+12.34}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.67\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.67\%$

Solving for the real return for $1975$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+5.87}{1+6.94}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.87\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.87\%$

Solving for the real return for $1976$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+5.07}{1+4.86}+1\\[15 pt]
&=2.04\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $2.04\%$

Solving for the real return for $1977$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+5.45}{1+6.70}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.84\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.84\%$

Solving for the real return for $1978$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+7.64}{1+9.02}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.86\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.86\%$

Solving for the real return for $1979$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+10.56}{1+13.29}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.81\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.81\%$

Solving for the real return for $1980$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Real return}&=\dfrac{1+12.10}{1+12.52}+1\\[15 pt]
&=1.97\%
\end{aligned}$$

The real return for this year is $1.97\%$

Now that we have the real returns for each year, we can now solve for the arithemtic average of the real returns by getting the sum and dividing it by the number of years. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Arithmetic real return}&=\dfrac{1.85+1.67+1.87+2.04+1.84+1.86+1.81+1.97}{8}\\[15 pt]
&=1.86\%
\end{aligned}$$

The arithmetic average for the real rate of return is $1.86\%$

**d.** Treasury bills are government-backed which means that they are safe since you have a guaranteed return no matter how small. However, since it is safe, the rewards are also not that big. The possible risk for treasury bills is if the government defaults the payment which is highly unlikely. However, this is not a good long-term investment as it does not have a lot of upside aside from it being risk-free.
